Kinshasa: the capital city of Zaire, formerly named Leopoldville.
kurchatovium: A transuranic element of atomic number 104, symbol Ku; also called rutherfordium, symbol Rf.  It is produced in very small quantities by nuclear reactions.  In November 1993 the nomenclature committe of the American Chemical Society approved the name rutherfordium for element 104.  Russsian investigators who claim to have first discovered element 104, isotope 260 (half-life 0.3 seconds) in 1964 at Dubna proposed the name kurchatovium.  However, investigators at Berkely in 1969 produced several isotopes of element 104 but were unable to produce isotope 260; they reported finding isotope 257, with a half-life of 4-5 seconds, isotope 259 with a half-life of 3-4 seconds, and isotope 258 with a shorter half-life.
Keelage: The right of demanding a duty or toll for a ship entering a port; also, the duty or toll.
Kneadable: That may be kneaded; capable of being worked into a mass.
Knife-edge: A piece of steel sharpened to an acute edge or angle, and resting on a smooth surface, serving as the axis of motion of a pendulum, scale beam, or other piece required to oscillate with the least possible friction.
Kiggelaria: A small genus of South African shrubs or small trees.
Kawaka: a New Zealand tree, the Cypress cedar (Libocedrus Doniana), having a valuable, fine-grained, reddish wood.
Knocking: A beating; a rap; a series of raps.
Kingtruss: A truss, framed with a king-post; -- used in roofs, bridges, etc.
Kneepiece: A piece shaped like a knee; as, the kneepieces or ears of a boat.
&Verbar;Krameria: A genus of spreading shrubs with many stems, from one species of which (Krameria triandra), found in Peru, rhatany root, used as a medicine, is obtained.
&Verbar;Kursaal: A public hall or room, for the use of visitors at watering places and health resorts in Germany.
Knurl: To provide with ridges, to assist the grasp, as in the edge of a flat knob, or coin; to mill.
Knighthead: A bollard timber. See under Bollard.
Knitback: The plant comfrey; -- so called from its use as a restorative.
kinetoscope: An instrument for producing curves by the combination of circular movements; -- called also kinescope.
Kecksy: The hollow stalk of an umbelliferous plant, such as the cow parsnip or the hemlock.
Kirghizia: A country in Central Asia, formerly an Asian Soviet.  It borders on Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, China, and Tajikistan.
Kraken: A fabulous Scandinavian sea monster, often represented as resembling an island, but sometimes as resembling an immense octopus.
Kerite: A compound in which tar or asphaltum combined with animal or vegetable oils is vulcanized by sulphur, the product closely resembling rubber; -- used principally as an insulating material in telegraphy.
Killock: A small anchor; also, a kind of anchor formed by a stone inclosed by pieces of wood fastened together.
Keyed: Furnished with keys; as, a keyed instrument; also, set to a key, as a tune.
Karaite: A sect of Jews who adhere closely to the letter of the Scriptures, rejecting the oral law, and allowing the Talmud no binding authority; -- opposed to the Rabbinists.
Kilnhole: The mouth or opening of an oven or kiln.
kephalin: One of a group of phospholipids (nitrogenous phosphorized fatty substances), present in all living cells and particularly noticeable in nervous tissue.  Same as cephalin, which see.
Knobstick: One who refuses to join, or withdraws from, a trade union.
Kaaba: The small and nearly cubical stone building, in the court of the Great Mosque at Mecca, toward which all Mohammedans must pray.  It contains a sacred black stone, believed by Mohammedans to be one of the precious stones of paradise, and to have been brought to Abraham when he was contructing the Kaaba, by the Angel Gabriel.  The Kaaba itself predates Mohammed, having been a pantheon which contained Arab idols, which were destroyed by Mohammed.
Kind-heartedness: The state or quality of being kind-hearted; benevolence.
Kilt: To tuck up; to truss up, as the clothes.
Kantist: A disciple or follower of Kant.
Kneebrush: A tuft or brush of hair on the knees of some species of antelopes and other animals; -- chiefly used in the plural.
Kiln: A large stove or oven; a furnace of brick or stone, or a heated chamber, for the purpose of hardening, burning, or drying anything; as, a kiln for baking or hardening earthen vessels; a kiln for drying grain, meal, lumber, etc.; a kiln for calcining limestone.
Keyboard: The whole arrangement, or one range, of the keys{3} of an organ, piano, typewriter, etc.; that part of a device containing the keys{3} used to operate it.
Kattimundoo: A caoutchouc-like substance obtained from the milky juice of the East Indian Euphorbia Kattimundoo. It is used as a cement.
kweek: A trailing grass (Cynodon dactylon) native to Europe, now cosmopolitan in warm regions; used for lawns and pastures especially in the Southern U. S. and India.  Called also Bahama grass and Bermuda grass.
Klicket: A small postern or gate in a palisade, for the passage of sallying parties.
Kitchen middens: Relics of neolithic man found on the coast of Denmark, consisting of shell mounds, some of which are ten feet high, one thousand feet long, and two hundred feet wide. The name is applied also to similar mounds found on the American coast from Canada to Florida, made by the North American Indians.
Kafal: The Arabian name of two trees of the genus Balsamodendron, which yield a gum resin and a red aromatic wood.
&Verbar;Krone: A coin of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, of the value of about twenty-eight cents (in 1913). See Crown, n., 9.
Kiplingesque: Of, pertaining to, or in the style of Rudyard Kipling.
knocker: One who, or that which, knocks; specifically, an instrument, or kind of hammer, fastened to a door, to be used in seeking for admittance.
Kneed: Having knees;- used chiefly in composition; as, in-kneed; out-kneed; weak-kneed.
Koluschan: Designating, or pertaining to, a linguistic stock of North American Indians comprising the Tlinkit tribes of the Alexander Archipelago of southeastern Alaska and adjacent coast lands. Their language bears some affinity to Mexican tongues.
Key-cold: Cold as a metallic key; lifeless.
Knappy: Having knaps; full of protuberances or humps; knobby.
Kingdomed: Having a kingdom or the dignity of a king; like a kingdom.
Kittle: Ticklish; not easily managed; troublesome; difficult; variable.
Kodachrome: A brand of photographic transparency bearing a positive color image.
Kneippism: Treatment of disease by forms of hydrotherapy, as walking barefoot in the morning dew, baths, wet compresses, cold affusions, etc.; -- so called from its originator, Sebastian Kneipp (1821-97), a German priest.
Kakaralli: A kind of wood common in Demerara, durable in salt water, because not subject to the depredations of the sea worm and barnacle.
&Verbar;Kali: The black, destroying goddess; -- called also Doorga, Anna Purna.
Kelpie: An imaginary spirit of the waters, horselike in form, vulgarly believed to warn, by preternatural noises and lights, those who are to be drowned.
Kalahari: A desert in Southwestern Africa, most of which is located in the country of Botswana.
Kolarian: An individual of one of the races of aboriginal inhabitants which survive in Hindustan.
Knobbler: The hart in its second year; a young deer.
Kantianism: The doctrine or theory of Kant; the Kantian philosophy.
Knighthood: The character, dignity, or condition of a knight, or of knights as a class; hence, chivalry.
Knacky: Having a knack; cunning; crafty; trickish.
Kitchenmaid: A woman employed in the kitchen.
Kingfisher: Any one of numerous species of birds constituting the family Alcedinidæ. Most of them feed upon fishes which they capture by diving and seizing them with the beak; others feed only upon reptiles, insects, etc. About one hundred and fifty species are known. They are found in nearly all parts of the world, but are particularly abundant in the East Indies.
K: the eleventh letter of the English alphabet, is nonvocal consonant. The form and sound of the letter K are from the Latin, which used the letter but little except in the early period of the language. It came into the Latin from the Greek, which received it from a Phœnician source, the ultimate origin probably being Egyptian.  Etymologically K is most nearly related to c, g, h (which see).
Keelson: A piece of timber in a ship laid on the middle of the floor timbers over the keel, and binding the floor timbers to the keel; in iron vessels, a structure of plates, situated like the keelson of a timber ship.
Kyley: an Australian boomerang, having one side flat and the other convex.
Koklass: Any pheasant of the genus Pucrasia.  The birds of this genus inhabit India and China, and are distinguished by having a long central and two lateral crests on the head.  Called also pucras.
Kobold: A kind of domestic spirit in German mythology, corresponding to the Scottish brownie and the English Robin Goodfellow.
knock-knee: A condition in which the knees are bent in so as to touch each other in walking; inknee.
Kernel: To harden or ripen into kernels; to produce kernels.
Kitty: A kitten; also, a pet name or calling name for the cat.
Kerned: Having part of the face projecting beyond the body or shank; -- said of type.
Kaross: A native garment or rug of skin sewed together in the form of a square.
klavern: A local chapter of the Ku Klux Klan.
Kenyapithecus: A genus of extinct primates having powerful chewing muscles along with large molars and small incisors; its fossils were found in Maboko in Kenya.
Kneepan: A roundish, flattened, sesamoid bone in the tendon in front of the knee joint; the patella; the kneecap.
Kleptomania: A propensity to steal, claimed to be irresistible. This does not constitute legal irresponsibility.
Knickerbocker: A descendent of the early Dutch colonists of the New York City area; --  used mostly as a nickname for an inhabitant of New York state or especially New York City.
Kneadingly: In the manner of one kneading.
Katsuwonidae: A natural family of fish which in some classifications is considered a separate family comprising the oceanic bonitos.
Keelfat: A cooler; a vat for cooling wort, etc.
Karpholite: A fibrous mineral occurring in tufts of a straw-yellow color. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and manganese.
Knicker: A small ball of clay, baked hard and oiled, used as a marble by boys in playing.
Kaynard: A lazy or cowardly person; a rascal.
&Verbar;Kalmia: A genus of North American shrubs with poisonous evergreen foliage and corymbs of showy flowers. Called also mountain laurel, ivy bush, lamb kill, calico bush, etc.
Kneel: To bend the knee; to fall or rest on the knees; -- sometimes with down.
kinase: One of a class of enzymes that catalyze transfer of a phosphate group from ATP to another molecule; it is a type of phosphorylase.
Kirk: A church or the church, in the various senses of the word; esp., the Church of Scotland as distinguished from other reformed churches, or from the Roman Catholic Church.
kinfolk: Relatives; kindred; kin; kinsfolk; persons of the same family or closely related families.
Keelivine: A pencil of black or red lead; -- called also keelyvine pen.
&Verbar;Keuper: The upper division of the European Triassic. See Chart of Geology.
Kelvin: The SI unit of temperature, defined as being 1/273.16 of the triple point of water; abbreviated K.  The melting point of water at 760 mm pressure is 273.15 Kelvins, and the boiling point 373.15 Kelvins.  One degree Kelvin is equal to one degree Centigrade, and 9/5 degrees Fahrenheit.
Kwannon: Japanese counterpart of the Chinese Kuan Yin.
Kaolin: A very pure white clay, ordinarily in the form of an impalpable powder, and used to form the paste of porcelain; China clay; porcelain clay. It is chiefly derived from the decomposition of common feldspar.
klaxon: a kind of loud horn formerly used on motor vehicles.
Knittle: A string that draws together a purse or bag.
Kafkaesque: Frightening, threating, and bewildering in a vague and unexplicable way; -- of situations or regulations.  Often used to describe illogical bureaucratic entanglements with no reasonable solution.
Kioways: A tribe of Indians distantly related to the Shoshones.  They formerly inhabited the region about the head waters of the North Platte.
Kipper: Amorous; also, lively; light-footed; nimble; gay; sprightly.
Kaolinization: The process by which feldspar is changed into kaolin.
King-post: A member of a common form of truss, as a roof truss. It is strictly a tie, intended to prevent the sagging of the tiebeam in the middle. If there are struts, supporting the main rafters, they often bear upon the foot of the king-post. Called also crown-post.
Kyanize: To render (wood) proof against decay by saturating with a solution of corrosive sublimate in open tanks, or under pressure.
Kaffir: One of a race which, with the Hottentots and Bushmen, inhabit South Africa. They inhabit the country north of Cape Colony, the name being now specifically applied to the tribes living between Cape Colony and Natal, including the Ponda, Xosa, and Tembu; but the Zulus of Natal are true Kaffirs.
Knitch: A number of things tied or knit together; a bundle; a fagot.
Kosher: To prepare in conformity with the requirements of the Jewish law, as meat.
Kain: Poultry, etc., required by the lease to be paid in kind by a tenant to his landlord.
Kail: A kind of headless cabbage. Same as Kale, 1.
Knotberry: The cloudberry (Rudus Chamæmorus); -- so called from its knotted stems.
Koodoo: A large South African antelope (Strepsiceros kudu). The males have graceful spiral horns, sometimes four feet long. The general color is reddish or grayish brown, with eight or nine white bands on each side, and a pale dorsal stripe. The old males become dark bluish gray, due to the skin showing through the hair. The females are hornless. Called also nellut.
Killifish: Any one of several small American cyprinodont fishes of the genus Fundulus and allied genera. They live equally well in fresh and brackish water, or even in the sea. They are usually striped or barred with black. Called also minnow, and brook fish. See Minnow.
Kinky: Full of kinks; liable to kink or curl; as, kinky hair.
Kalong: A fruit bat, esp. the Indian edible fruit bat (Pteropus edulis).
Kingcraft: The craft of kings; the art of governing as a sovereign; royal policy.
Khond: A Dravidian of a group of tribes of Orissa, India, a section of whom were formerly noted for their cruel human sacrifices to the earth goddess, murder of female infants, and marriage by capture.
Keeler: One employed in managing a Newcastle keel; -- called also keelman.
Knotwort: A small, herbaceous, trailing plant, of the genus Illecebrum (Illecebrum verticillatum).
&Verbar;Kahani: A kind of notary public, or attorney, in the Levant.
Kingbolt: A vertical iron bolt, by which the forward axle and wheels of a vehicle or the trucks of a railroad car are connected with the other parts.
Keeled: Keel-shaped; having a longitudinal prominence on the back; as, a keeled leaf.
&Verbar;Korrigum: A West African antelope (Damalis Senegalensis), allied to the sassaby. It is reddish gray, with a black face, and a black stripe on the outside of the legs above the knees.
Komtok: An African freshwater fish (Protopterus annectens), belonging to the Dipnoi. It can breathe air by means of its lungs, and when waters dry up, it encases itself in a nest of hard mud, where it remains till the rainy season. It is used as food.
Kibblings: Portions of small fish used for bait on the banks of Newfoundland.
&Verbar;Kibitka: A tent used by the Kirghiz Tartars.
Kindergarten: A class within a primary school or a separate school for young children, usually between the ages of four and six years, designed to adapt children to the classroom environment before beginning academic training, on the theory that education should be begun by gratifying and cultivating the normal aptitude for exercise, play, observation, imitation, and construction; -- a name given by Friedrich Froebel, a German educator, who introduced this method of training, in rooms opening on a garden.
&Verbar;Kalpa: One of the Brahmanic eons, a period of 4,320,000,000 years. At the end of each Kalpa the world is annihilated.
Kyriolexy: The use of literal or simple expressions, as distinguished from the use of figurative or obscure ones.
Khutbah: An address or public prayer read from the steps of the pulpit in Mohammedan mosques, offering glory to God, praising Mohammed and his descendants, and the ruling princes.
Klipspringer: A small, graceful South African antelope (Nanotragus oreotragus), which, like the chamois, springs from one crag to another with great agility; -- called also kainsi.
Kiva: A large chamber built under, or in, the houses of a Pueblo village, used as an assembly room in religious rites or as a men's dormitory. It is commonly lighted and entered from an opening in the roof.
kinaesthesia: The perception attendant upon the movements of the muscles; the sensation accompanying movement of the muscles.
Kotow: To perform the kotow.  Now usually spelled kowtow.
Kabook: A clay ironstone found in Ceylon.
Kneeler: One who kneels or who worships by or while kneeling.
Kindling: The act of causing to burn, or of exciting or inflaming the passions.
Killing: Literally, that kills; having power to kill; fatal; in a colloquial sense, conquering; captivating; irresistible.
Keramographic: Suitable to be written upon; capable of being written upon, as a slate; -- said especially of a certain kind of globe.
Kelpfish: A small California food fish (Heterostichus rostratus), living among kelp. The name is also applied to species of the genus Platyglossus.
Kat: An Arabian shrub (Catha edulis) the leaves of which are used as tea by the Arabs.
Kinsman: A man of the same race or family; one related by blood.
Keckle: To wind old rope around, as a cable, to preserve its surface from being fretted, or to wind iron chains around, to defend from the friction of a rocky bottom, or from the ice.
Knack: A petty contrivance; a toy; a plaything; a knickknack.
Kippernut: A name given to earthnuts of several kinds.
Kshatriya: The military caste, the second of the four great Hindu castes; also, a member of that caste. See Caste.
Kefir grains: Small hard yellowish aggregations found in the Caucasus region, and containing various yeasts and bacteria. They are used as a ferment in preparing kefir.
kleagle: An officer, especially an attorney, of the Ku Klux Klan.
Kemps: The long flower stems of the ribwort plantain (Plantago Lanceolata).
Kymograph: An instrument for measuring, and recording graphically, the pressure of the blood in any of the blood vessels of a living animal; -- called also kymographion.
Khanate: Dominion or jurisdiction of a khan.
kitten-tails: a plant of the genus Besseya having fluffy spikes of flowers.
Kusimanse: A carnivorous animal (Crossarchus obscurus) of tropical Africa. It its allied to the civets. Called also kusimansel, and mangue.
Knowable: That may be known; capable of being discovered, understood, or ascertained.
komondor: A Hungarian breed of large powerful shaggy-coated white dog, used also as guard dog.
Knaggy: Knotty; rough; figuratively, rough in temper.
Keynesianism: the macroeconomic theories and politico-economic policies of British economist John Maynard Keynes (1883-1946) and his followers; -- used especially in reference to their advocacy of governmental action to maintain low unemployment through government spending.  See Keynes.
kick back: To pay (a kickback); as, they kicked back five percent of the sales price.
Kaiser: The ancient title of emperors of Germany assumed by King William of Prussia when crowned sovereign of the new German empire in 1871.
kangaroos-foot: A sedgelike spring-flowering herb (Anigozanthus manglesii) of Australia, having clustered flowers covered with woolly hairs.
Kousso: An Abyssinian rosaceous tree (Brayera anthelmintica), the flowers of which are used as a vermifuge.
KOd: rendered unconscious, usually by a blow.
Knobbed: Containing knobs; full of knobs; ending in a nob. See Illust of Antenna.
Kilderkin: A small barrel; an old liquid measure containing eighteen English beer gallons, or nearly twenty-two gallons, United States measure.
Kerchiefed: Dressed; hooded; covered; wearing a kerchief.
Kanchenjunga: A mountain in India and Nepal, 28,146 feet high.
&Verbar;Khedive: A governor or viceroy; -- a title granted in 1867 by the sultan of Turkey to the ruler of Egypt.
kinetic: Moving or causing motion; motory; active, as opposed to latent.
Kinetoscope: An obsolete form of moving picture viewer, in which a film carrying successive instantaneous views of a moving scene travels uniformly through the field of a magnifying glass. The observer sees each picture, momentarily, through a slit in a revolving disk, and these glimpses, blended by persistence of vision, give the impression of continuous motion.  It has been superseded by more recent versions of movie projector and electronic video viewers.
knowledge-intensive: Requiring access to and manipulation of large quantities of knowledge; as, knowledge-intensive labor.
Kissing strings: Cap or bonnet strings made long to tie under the chin.
Keepsake: Anything kept, or given to be kept, for the sake of the giver; a token of friendship.
Kindler: One who, or that which, kindles, stirs up, or sets on fire.
Knight marshal: An officer in the household of the British sovereign, who has cognizance of transgressions within the royal household and verge, and of contracts made there, a member of the household being one of the parties.
Knickerbockers: The name for a style of short breeches; smallclothes; called also knickers.
Knockdown: Of force sufficient to fell or completely overthrow; as, a knockdown blow; a knockdown argument..
Kilting: A perpendicular arrangement of flat, single plaits, each plait being folded so as to cover half the breadth of the preceding one.
Keeper: One who, or that which, keeps; one who, or that which, holds or has possession of anything.
Kirschwasser: An alcoholic liquor, obtained by distilling the fermented juice of the small black cherry.
Kibed: Chapped; cracked with cold; affected with chilblains; as, kibed heels.
Kanacka: A native of the Sandwich Islands.
Krummhorn: A reed instrument of music of the cornet kind, now obsolete (see Cornet, 1, a.).
Keeve: To set in a keeve, or tub, for fermentation.
Karob: The twenty-fourth part of a grain; -- a weight used by goldsmiths.
keel over: To drop down in a faint, or as if dead; to die.
Kapok: A silky wool derived from the seeds of Ceiba pentandra (syn. Eriodendron anfractuosum), a bombaceous tree of the East and West Indies.
Kuklux: The name adopted in the southern part of the United States by a secret political organization, active for several years after the close of the Civil War, and having for its aim the repression of the political power of the freed negroes; -- called also Kuklux Klan and the Klan.  It exerienced a revival in the 1920's, in the north as well as the south, and persists as a weak organization into the 1990's.  Its goals were primarily anti-negro and anti-Catholic, and its tactics included terrorist attacks on negroes for the purpose of intimidation with the goal of continuing segregation.  The signature activity of the Klan was the burning of a cross, either at rallies of Klansmen, or on the property of African-Americans which they hoped to intimidate.
Kemp: Coarse, rough hair in wool or fur, injuring its quality.
Kill-joy: One who causes gloom or grief; a dispiriting person; a spoilsport.
ketchup: A pureed table sauce made predominantly from tomatoes, flavored with onions, sugar, salt and spices; called also tomato ketchup. The term is also applied to pureed sauces containing mushrooms, walnuts, etc., being called in such cases mushroom ketchup, walnut ketchup, etc.
Knowingly: With knowledge; in a knowing manner; intelligently; consciously; deliberately; as, he would not knowingly offend.
Kolinsky: Among furriers, any of several Asiatic minks; esp., Putorius sibiricus, the yellowish brown pelt of which is valued, esp. for the tail, used for making artists' brushes. Trade names for the fur are red sable and Tatar sable.
Knavish: Like or characteristic of a knave{3}; given to knavery; trickish; fraudulent; dishonest; villainous; as, a knavish fellow, or a knavish trick.
Keenness: The quality or state of being keen.
Knightly: In a manner becoming a knight.
Keyseat: To form a key seat, as by cutting. See Key seat, under Key.
Kenya: A country in East Africa, formerly a British colony.
Krakowiak: A lively Polish dance. See Cracovienne.
Karyostenotic: Pertaining to, or connected with, karyostenosis; as, the karyostenotic mode of nuclear division.
knockout: Act of knocking out, or state of being knocked out; the act of rendering a person unconscious by a blow.
Keckling: Old rope or iron chains wound around a cable. See Keckle, v. t.
Kiddy: A young fellow; formerly, a low thief.
Kathetal: Making a right angle; perpendicular, as two lines or two sides of a triangle, which include a right angle.
Kraal: A collection of huts within a stockade; a village; sometimes, a single hut.
Kalasie: A long-tailed monkey of Borneo (Semnopithecus rubicundus). It has a tuft of long hair on the head.
Kamet: A mountain in India and Tibet, 25,447 feet high.
kolkhoz: A collective farm owned by the communist state, in the former USSR.
klatch: An informal group that gathers more or less frequently, especially for conversation; as, a coffee klatsch; a sewing klatsch.
knitwork: A network of yarn created by interlacing threads of yarn in a series of connected loops using straight eyeless needles or by machine; knitting.
Ken: Cognizance; view; especially, reach of sight or knowledge.
Keslop: The stomach of a calf, prepared for rennet.
Karmathian: One of a Mohammedan sect founded in the ninth century by Karmat.
Kindred: Related; congenial; of the like nature or properties; as, kindred souls; kindred skies; kindred propositions.
Kea: A large New Zealand parrot (Nestor notabilis), notorious for having acquired the habit of killing sheep; -- called also mountain parrot.
Key: To fasten or secure firmly; to fasten or tighten with keys or wedges.
Kerchief: A square of fine linen worn by women as a covering for the head; hence, anything similar in form or material, worn for ornament on other parts of the person; -- mostly used in compounds; as, neckerchief; breastkerchief; and later, handkerchief.
Kingliness: The state or quality of being kingly.
Knee jerk reaction: an immediate unthinking emotional reaction produced by an event or statement to which the reacting person is highly sensitive; -- in persons with strong feelings on a topic, it may be very predictable.
Kulturkampf: Lit., culture war; -- a name, originating with Virchow (1821 - 1902), given to a struggle between the Roman Catholic Church and the German government, chiefly over the latter's efforts to control educational and ecclesiastical appointments in the interest of the political policy of centralization. The struggle began with the passage by the Prussian Diet in May, 1873, of the so-called May laws, or Falk laws, aiming at the regulation of the clergy.  Opposition eventually compelled the government to change its policy, and from 1880 to 1887 laws virtually nullifying the May laws were enacted.
Kitchenette: A room combining a very small kitchen and a pantry, with the kitchen conveniences compactly arranged, sometimes so that they fold up out of sight and allow the kitchen to be made a part of the adjoining room by opening folding doors.
knuckles: a small metal weapon, worn over the knuckles on the back of the hand; called also brass knuckles and knuckle duster.
&Verbar;Koulan: A wild horse (Equus onager or Asinus onager) inhabiting the plains of Central Asia; -- called also gour, khur, and onager.
Knock-out: That knocks out; characterized by knocking out; as, a knock-out blow; a knock-out key for knocking out a drill from a collet.
Knave: A boy; especially, a boy servant.
&Verbar;Krait: A very venomous snake of India (Bungarus cœruleus), allied to the cobra.  Its upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often with narrow white streaks; the belly is whitish.
Kruppize: To treat by, or subject to, the Krupp process.
Knavery: The practices of a knave; petty villainy; fraud; trickery; a knavish action.
Knight bachelor: A knight of the most ancient, but lowest, order of English knights, and not a member of any order of chivalry. See Bachelor, 4.
&Verbar;Karakul: A type of Astrakhan, esp. in fine grades, obtained from the Karakul sheep.  See sense 2 and cf. Caracul.
Kabyle: A Berber, as in Algiers or Tunis. See Berber.
Kestrel: A small, slender European hawk (Falco alaudarius), allied to the sparrow hawk. Its color is reddish fawn, streaked and spotted with white and black. Also called windhover and stannel. The name is also applied to other allied species.
Kipling: Rudyard Kipling, English author (1865-1936).  He was born at Bombay, India in 1865, the son of John Lockwood Kipling, who was formerly head of the Lahore School of Industrial Art.  He was educated in England and returned to India in 1880 as editor of the “Lahore Civil and Military Gazette.”   He returned to England about 1889, and lived several years in the United States.   While in India he published stories, sketches, and poems descriptive of India and Anglo-Indian military and civil life: “ Departmental Ditties, etc.”, “Plain Tales from the Hills”, “Mine Own People”, “Soldiers Three”, “Barrack-room Ballads, etc.”, and others.  After leaving India he published “The Light That Failed,” “Naulahka” (with Balestier), “Many Inventions,” “The Jungle Book,”  “The Second Jungle Book,” “The Seven Seas,” “Captains Courageous,” “The White Man's Burden,” “Kim,” “The Man Who Would Be King and Other Stories,” and others.
kiley: An Australian boomerang, having one side flat and the other convex.
Kieserite: Hydrous sulphate of magnesia found at the salt mines of Stassfurt, Prussian Saxony.
kalian: A pipe with a long flexible tube connected to a container where the smoke is cooled by passing through water.  See also hookah.
Ketol: One of a series of series of complex nitrogenous substances, represented by methyl ketol and related to indol.
Kedge: A small anchor used whenever a large one can be dispensed with. See Kedge, v. t., and Anchor, n.
Kinghood: The state of being a king; the attributes of a king; kingship.
Kersey: A kind of coarse, woolen cloth, usually ribbed, woven from wool of long staple.
Kolkwitzia: A Chinese genus having only one species, the beauty bush.
&Verbar;Koftgari: Ornamental work produced by inlaying steel with gold, -- a variety of damascening much used in the arts of India.
kiaat: a deciduous South African tree (Pterocarpus angolensis) having large odd-pinnate leaves and profuse fragrant orange-yellow flowers; it yields a red juice and heavy strong durable wood.
K2: A mountain in Northern Kashmir; it is one of the highest in the world, 28,250 feet high.
knavishness: The quality or state of being knavish; knavery; dishonesty.
knowledge worker: A person whose occupation is predominantly concerned with generating or interpreting information, as contrasted with manual labor.
Knottiness: The quality or state of being knotty or full of knots.
Know-nothingism: The doctrines, principles, or practices, of the Know-nothings.
Kilostere: A cubic measure containing 1000 cubic meters, and equivalent to 35,315 cubic feet.
Kohl: A mixture of soot and other ingredients, used by Egyptian and other Eastern women to darken the edges of the eyelids.
Kobellite: A blackish gray mineral, a sulphide of antimony, bismuth, and lead.
Kern baby: A doll or image decorated with corn (grain) flowers, etc., carried in the festivals of a kern, or harvest-home. Called also harvest queen.
kos: an Indian unit of length having different values in different localities.
Klansman: a member of the Ku Klux Klan.
Ka: An unknown god; an epithet of Prajapati and Brahma.
Kingbird: A small American bird (Tyrannus tyrannus, or Tyrannus Carolinensis), noted for its courage in attacking larger birds, even hawks and eagles, especially when they approach its nest in the breeding season. It is a typical tyrant flycatcher, taking various insects upon the wing. It is dark ash above, and blackish on the bead and tail. The quills and wing coverts are whitish at the edges. It is white beneath, with a white terminal band on the tail. The feathers on the head of the adults show a bright orange basal spot when erected. Called also bee bird, and bee martin. Several Southern and Western species of Tyrannus are also called king birds.
Ki: The Sumerian goddess personifying earth; the counterpart of Akkadian Aruru.
Kr: The chemical symbol for the element krypyon, one of the six noble gasses.
&Verbar;Kagu: A singular, crested, grallatorial bird (Rhinochetos jubatus), native of New Caledonia.  It is gray above, paler beneath, and the feathers of the wings and tail are handsomely barred with brown, black, and gray.  It is allied to the sun bittern.
Koolokamba: A west African anthropoid ape (Troglodytes koolokamba, or Troglodytes Aubryi), allied to the chimpanzee and gorilla, and, in some respects, intermediate between them.
knockout drops: Drops of any drug, used to a person to fall asleep or become unconscious or stupefied for the purpose of robbery, etc.; they are usually mixed into a drink so that the person consuming it does so unknowingly.  One compound used for this purpose is chloral hydrate.
Kairoline: An organic base obtained from quinoline. It is used as a febrifuge, and resembles kairine.
Keech: A mass or lump of fat rolled up by the butcher.
keyword: A word used as an entry point into an index which serves to identify files, records, texts, or other data containing the key or some related word, such as a synonym.  It is a type of key{15}; as, a boolean combination of keywords is more effective for information retrieval than a single key{15}.
&Verbar;Karyokinesis: The indirect division of cells in which, prior to division of the cell protoplasm, complicated changes take place in the nucleus, attended with movement of the nuclear fibrils; -- opposed to karyostenosis. The nucleus becomes enlarged and convoluted, and finally the threads are separated into two groups which ultimately become disconnected and constitute the daughter nuclei. Called also mitosis. See Cell development, under Cell.
Karagane: A species of gray fox found in Russia.
KO: To knock out; to deliver a blow that renders (the opponent) unconscious; -- used especially in boxing.
Kingfish: An American marine food fish of the genus Menticirrus, especially Menticirrus saxatilis, or Menticirrus nebulosos, of the Atlantic coast; -- called also whiting, surf whiting, and barb.
karate: a traditional Japanese system of unarmed combat; sharp blows and kicks are given to pressure-sensitive points on the body of the opponent.
Kentledge: Pigs of iron used for ballast.
Kamsin: A hot southwesterly wind in Egypt, coming from the Sahara.
Keeping: A holding; restraint; custody; guard; charge; care; preservation.
Kilometer: A measure of length, being a thousand meters. It is equal to 3,280.84 feet, or 0.62137119 of a mile.
Kinematics: The science which treats of motions considered in themselves, or apart from their causes; the comparison and relation of motions.
kick off: to begin; to commence; as, they kicked off the rally with a playing of the national anthem.
Kidderminster: A kind of ingrain carpeting, named from the English town where formerly most of it was manufactured.
King Charles spaniel: A variety of small pet dogs, having, drooping ears, a high, dome-shaped forehead, pug nose, large, prominent eyes, and long, wavy hair. The color is usually black and tan.
Kremlin: The citadel of a town or city; especially, the citadel of Moscow, a large inclosure which contains imperial palaces, cathedrals, churches, an arsenal, etc.
Knight Templar: See Commandery, n., 3, and also Templar, n., 1 and 3.
Khaki: Any kind of khaki cloth; hence, a uniform of khaki or, rarely, a soldier clad in khaki. In the United States and British armies khaki or cloth of a very similar color is almost exclusively used for service in the field.
Knock-off: That knocks off; of or pertaining to knocking off.
knead: To perform movements like kneading, with the paws; -- said of cats, which may knead{3} a master's body when stroked, presumably a sign of contentment; as, a cat kneading and purring in his master's lap.
Kip: A sharp-pointed hill; a projecting point, as on a hill.
Kish: A workman's name for the graphite which forms incidentally in iron smelting.
Kist: A stated payment, especially a payment of rent for land; hence, the time for such payment.
Kin: Of the same nature or kind; kinder.
Kiss: To make or give salutation with the lips in token of love, respect, etc.; as, kiss and make friends.
Killdee: A small American plover (Charadrius vociferus, formerly Ægialitis vocifera) of inland waters and fields having a distinctive cry.  The adult has two black bands around the neck and upper breast, but the young chick has only the breast band.  It ranges from Canada to Mexico and the West Indies.
Kairine: A pale buff or white crystalline alkaloid derived from quinoline, and used as an antipyretic in medicine.
kneecap: to break the knees of, especially by shooting in the kneecap; -- often done by criminal or terrorist groups as a warning or punishment.
Kamptulicon: A kind of elastic floor cloth, made of India rubber, gutta-percha, linseed oil, and powdered cork.
kibbutz: an Israeli communal{2} form of agricultural settlement. Originally it was predominantly agricultural and practiced a very high level of sharing, including collective rearing of children. More recently (by 1998) industries have taken over a significant role in the Kibbutz economy, and the level of sharing has dropped significantly.
Knight: To dub or create (one) a knight; -- done in England by the sovereign only, who taps the kneeling candidate with a sword, saying: Rise, Sir ---.
Kaligenous: Forming alkalies with oxygen, as some metals.
kinetophone: A machine combining a kinetoscope and a phonograph synchronized so as to reproduce a scene and its accompanying sounds.  It has been superseded by recording techniques allowing the sounds to be recorded directly on the motion-picture film.
Kohinoor: A famous diamond, surrendered to the British crown on the annexation of the Punjab.  According to Hindu legends, it was found in a Golconda mine, and has been the property of various Hindu and Persian rulers.
Kanawha: The Kanawha River, a tributary of the Ohio River.
Kettledrummer: One who plays on a kettledrum.
Knapweed: The black centaury (Centaurea nigra); -- so called from the knoblike heads of flowers. Called also bullweed.
Kerf: A notch, channel, or slit made in any material by cutting or sawing.
Kyrielle: A litany beginning with the words, “Kyrie eleison.”
Knotted: Full of knots; having knots; knurled; as, a knotted cord; the knotted oak.
Kingston: The black angel fish. See Angel fish, under Angel.
Kainit: Salts of potassium used in the manufacture of fertilizers.
Knowingness: The state or quality of being knowing or intelligent; shrewdness; skillfulness.
Knapple: To break off with an abrupt, sharp noise; to bite; to nibble.
Kendal green: A cloth colored green by dye obtained from the woad-waxen, formerly used by Flemish weavers at Kendal, in Westmoreland, England.
Kier: A large tub or vat in which goods are subjected to the action of hot lye or bleaching liquor; -- also called keeve.
&Verbar;Ketmie: The name of certain African species of Hibiscus, cultivated for the acid of their mucilage.
Kinglet: A little king; a weak or insignificant king.
Kidnaper: One who steals or forcibly carries away a human being; a manstealer.
Keno: A gambling game, a variety of the game of lotto, played with balls or knobs, numbered, and cards also numbered.
Koellia: The genus comprising the American mountain mint, synonymous with Pycnanthemum.
Keilhauite: A mineral of a brownish black color, related to titanite in form. It consists chiefly of silica, titanium dioxide, lime, and yttria.
Kingly: In a kingly or kinglike manner.
kalantas: A Philippine timber tree (Toona calantas or Cedrela calantas) having hard red fragrant wood.
Komenic: Of or pertaining to, or designating, an acid derived from meconic acid.
Kneck: The twisting of a rope or cable, as it is running out.
Kingdom: The rank, quality, state, or attributes of a king; royal authority; sovereign power; rule; dominion; monarchy.
killable: fit to kill, especially for food.
Knitting: The work of a knitter; the network formed by knitting; knitwork.
Keepership: The office or position of a keeper.
Kansas: A tribe of Indians allied to the Winnebagoes and Osages. They formerly inhabited the region which is now the State of Kansas, but were removed to the Indian Territory.
Knock down: To strike down; to fell; to prostrate by a blow or by blows; as, to knock down an assailant.
Kilo-: A combining form used to signify thousand in forming the names of units of measurement; as, kilogram, kilometer, kilowatt, etc.
Kistvaen: A Celtic monument, commonly known as a dolmen.
Keratose: Containing hornlike fibers or fibers of keratose; belonging to the Keratosa.
Kicker: One who, or that which, kicks.
Kleeneboc: An antelope (Cerphalopus pygmæus), found in South Africa. It is of very small size, being but one foot high at the shoulder. It is remarkable for its activity, and for its mild and timid disposition. Called also guevi, and pygmy antelope.
Knee-high: Rising or reaching upward to the knees; as, the water is knee-high.
Knowa bleness: The state or quality of being knowable.
Knubs: Waste silk formed in winding off the threads from a cocoon.
Kilogram: A measure of weight, being a thousand grams, equal to 2.2046226 pounds avoirdupois (15,432.34 grains). It is equal to the weight of a cubic decimeter of distilled water at the temperature of maximum density, or 39° Fahrenheit.
Keep: The act or office of keeping; custody; guard; care; heed; charge.
Krang: The carcass of a whale after the blubber has been removed.
Keen: To wail as a keener does.
Keel: To traverse with a keel; to navigate.
kickoff: A kick from the center of the field to start a football game or to resume it after a score.
kittenish: Resembling a kitten; playful; as, a kittenish disposition.
kike: A derogatory name for a jew, usually intended and taken as disparaging and offensive.
Knotty: Full of knots; knotted; having many knots; as, knotty timber; a knotty rope.
kickback: recoil, of a gun or machine, as in older automobile engines when started by turning a crank.
Korinthos: A city in Greece; the modern city is near the site of the ancient city that was 2nd only to Athens in size and power in ancient Greece.
katabolic: Of or pertaining to catabolism; same as catabolic.
Knuckle: To beat with the knuckles; to pummel.
Kahau: A long-nosed monkey (Nasalis larvatus, formerly Semnopithecus nasalis), native of Borneo. The general color of the body is bright chestnut, with the under parts, shoulders, and sides of the head, golden yellow, and the top of the head and upper part of the back brown. Called also proboscis monkey.  It is now an endangered species.
Kaleege: One of several species of large, crested, Asiatic pheasants, belonging to the genus Euplocamus, and allied to the firebacks.
knickers: The name for a style of loose-fitting short trousers, gathered in and ending at the knees; smallclothes; called also knickerbockers.
keyless: lacking or not requiring a key; as, a keyless lock operated by a series of pushbuttons.  Opposite of keyed.
&Verbar;Kloof: A glen; a ravine closed at its upper end.
King: To supply with a king; to make a king of; to raise to royalty.
&Verbar;Kalki: The name of Vishnu in his tenth and last avatar.
Kummel: A Russian and German liqueur, consisting of a sweetened spirit flavored with caraway seeds.
Kind-hearted: Having kindness of nature; sympathetic; characterized by a humane disposition; as, a kind-hearted landlord.
Kudos: To praise; to extol; to glorify.
Kislev: the third month of the Jewish civil year; the ninth month of the ecclesiastical year in the Jewish calendar, occupying a part of November and a part of December.
Kipe: An osier basket used for catching fish.
Kavass: An armed constable; also, a government servant or courier.
Knopped: Having knops or knobs; fastened as with buttons.
Knockabout: A small yacht, generally from fifteen to twenty-five feet in length, having a mainsail and a jib; a sloop with a simplified rig and no bowsprit.  All knockabouts have ballast and either a keel or centerboard.  The original type was twenty-one feet in length.  The next larger type is called a raceabout.
Kilowatt hour: A unit of work or energy equal to that done by one kilowatt acting for one hour; -- approximately equal to 1.34 horse-power hour.
Krameric: Pertaining to, or derived from, Krameria (rhatany); as, krameric acid, usually called ratanhia-tannic acid.
&Verbar;Kapelle: A chapel; hence, the choir or orchestra of a prince's chapel; now, a musical establishment, usually orchestral.
Kyloes: The cattle of the Hebrides, or of the Highlands.
kinetogenesis: The doctrine or hypothesis that animal structures have been produced, directly or indirectly, by animal movements.
Keystone State: Pennsylvania; -- a nickname alluding to its having been the central one of the 13 original United States, at the time of formation of the Constitution.
Kamtschadales: An aboriginal tribe inhabiting the southern part of the Kamchatka peninsula; called also Kamchadals and Itelmen.
Kitten: To bring forth young, as a cat; to bring forth, as kittens.
kangaroo: Any one of numerous species of jumping marsupials of the family Macropodidæ.  They inhabit Australia, New Guinea, and adjacent islands, They have long and strong hind legs and a large tail, while the fore legs are comparatively short and feeble.  The giant kangaroo (Macropus major) is the largest species, sometimes becoming twelve or fourteen feet in total length.  The tree kangaroos, belonging to the genus Dendrolagus, live in trees; the rock kangaroos, of the genus Petrogale, inhabit rocky situations; and the brush kangaroos, of the genus Halmaturus, inhabit wooded districts. See Wallaby.
Knawel: A low, spreading weed (Scleranthus annuus), common in sandy soil.
Kitchen: To furnish food to; to entertain with the fare of the kitchen.
Kino: The dark red dried juice of certain plants, used variously in tanning, in dyeing, and as an astringent in medicine.
Kink: A fit of coughing; also, a convulsive fit of laughter.
Kiloliter: A measure of capacity equal to a cubic meter, or a thousand liters. It is equivalent to 35.315 cubic feet, and to 220.04 imperial gallons, or 264.18 American gallons of 321 cubic inches.
Kapia: The fossil resin of the kauri tree of New Zealand.
Kivikivi: Any species of Apteryx, esp. Apteryx australis; -- so called in imitation of its notes.  More commonly called kiwi. See Apteryx.
kicking: The act of delivering a blow with the foot.
Kage: A chantry chapel inclosed with lattice or screen work.
Kitcat: A game played by striking with a stick small piece of wood, called a cat, shaped like two cones united at their bases; tipcat.
key: Essential; most important; as, the key fact in the inquiry; the president was the key player inthe negotiations.
Keynes: John Maynard Keynes, the british economist (1883-1946) whose book “The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money” (Macmillan, 1936) had a strong influence on views of the government's role in the economy through the 1970's.  See Keynesian.
Kerchered: Covered, or bound round, with a kercher.
Kritarchy: The rule of the judges over Israel.
killing: The act or process of causing a living organism to die.
Koala: A tailless furry marsupial (Phascolarctos cinereus), found in Australia. The female carries her young on the back of her neck. Called also Australian bear, koala bear, native bear, and native sloth.  The koala lives almost all of its life in trees, moves sluggishly like a sloth, and eats eucalyptus leaves almost exclusively.
Kennel: To put or keep in a kennel.
Khaya: A lofty West African tree (Khaya Senegalensis), related to the mahogany, which it resembles in the quality of the wood. The bark is used as a febrifuge.
Kowtow: To perform the kowtow.  Same as Kotow
king-size: extra large; as, a king-size bed.
&Verbar;Kami: A title given to the celestial gods of the first mythical dynasty of Japan and extended to the demigods of the second dynasty, and then to the long line of spiritual princes still represented by the mikado.
Kranging hook: A hook for holding the blubber while cutting it away.
&Verbar;Keratonyxis: The operation of removing a cataract by thrusting a needle through the cornea of the eye, and breaking up the opaque mass.
&Verbar;Karyostenosis: Direct cell division (in which there is first a simple division of the nucleus, without any changes in its structure, followed by division of the protoplasm of the cell); -- in opposition to karyokinesis.
Karen: A language spoken in the Thai-Burmese borderlands.
Knell: To summon, as by a knell.
Knurly: Full of knots; hard; tough; hence, capable of enduring or resisting much.
Krupp gun: A breech-loading steel cannon manufactured at the works of Friedrich Krupp, at Essen in Prussia.  Guns of over eight-inch bore are made up of several concentric cylinders; those of a smaller size are forged solid.
Kainite: A compound salt consisting chiefly of potassium chloride and magnesium sulphate, occurring at the Stassfurt salt mines in Prussian Saxony.
Kiteflying: A mode of raising money, or sustaining one's credit, by the use of paper which is merely nominal; -- called also kiting.
Kiln-dry: To dry in a kiln; as, to kiln-dry meal or grain.
&Verbar;Kieselguhr: Siliceous earth; diatomaceous earth; specifically, porous infusorial earth, used as an absorbent of nitroglycerin in the manufacture of dynamite.
kazoo: A kind of toy or rude musical instrument, as a tube inside of which is a stretched string or membrane made to vibrate by singing or humming into the tube.
Kettle: A metallic vessel, with a wide mouth, often without a cover, used for heating and boiling water or other liguids.
Killow: An earth of a blackish or deep blue color.
Kyar: Cocoanut fiber, or the cordage made from it. See Coir.
Knights fee: The fee of a knight; specif., the amount of land the holding of which imposed the obligation of knight service, being sometimes a hide{1}(b) or less, sometimes six or more hides.
karyoplasm: The protoplasmic substance of the nucleus of a cell; nucleoplasm; -- in opposition to cytoplasm, the protoplasm of the cell.
Kermes: The dried bodies of the females of a scale insect (Kermes ilices formerly Coccus ilicis), allied to the cochineal insect, and found on several species of oak near the Mediterranean; also, the dye obtained from them.  They are round, about the size of a pea, contain coloring matter analogous to carmine, and are used in dyeing. They were anciently thought to be of a vegetable nature, and were used in medicine.
&Verbar;Kauri: A tall coniferous tree of New Zealand Agathis australis, or Dammara australis), having white straight-grained wood furnishing valuable timber and also yielding one kind of dammar resin.
Knoll: The tolling of a bell; a knell.
Knobbing: Rough dressing by knocking off knobs or projections.
Kissing bug: Any one of several species of blood-sucking, venomous Hemiptera that sometimes bite the lip or other parts of the human body, causing painful sores, as the cone-nose (Conorhinus sanguisuga).
knobkerrie: A short wooden club with a knobbed end used as a missile weapon by Kafir and other native tribes of South Africa.
Kra: A long-tailed ape (Macacus cynomolgus) of India and Sumatra. It is reddish olive, spotted with black, and has a black tail.
kurchee: A tropical Asian tree (Holarrhena antidysenterica syn. Holarrhena pubescens) with hard white wood and bark formerly used as a remedy for dysentery and diarrhea.
Kyack: A pack sack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle.
Kiosk: A Turkish open summer house or pavilion, supported by pillars.
-kin: A diminutive suffix; as, manikin; lambkin.
Kyriological: Serving to denote objects by conventional signs or alphabetical characters; as, the original Greek alphabet of sixteen letters was called kyriologic, because it represented the pure elementary sounds. See Curiologic.
Knavishly: In a knavish manner; dishonestly; fraudulently.
Keratophyte: A gorgonian coral having a horny axis.
kinesthetics: The ability to feel movements of the limbs and body.
Kalium: Potassium; -- so called by the German chemists.
knockabout: Marked by knocking about or roughness.
&Verbar;Kama: The Hindu Cupid. He is represented as a beautiful youth, with a bow of sugar cane or flowers.
Krypton: An inert gaseous element of the argon (noble gas) group, of atomic number 36, occurring in air to the extent of about one volume in a million.  It was discovered by Ramsay and Travers in 1898.  Boiling point, -152.3° C.; melting point, -156.6° C.; symbol, Kr; atomic weight, 83.8.
Kwan yin: A female Bodhisattva; often called Goddess of Mercy and considered an aspect of the Bodisattva Avalokitesvara; identified with Japanese Kwannon.
katharsis: purging of emotional tensions; -- usually spelled catharsis.
Know-nothing: A member of a secret political organization in the United States, the chief objects of which were the proscription of foreigners by the repeal of the naturalization laws, and the exclusive choice of native Americans for office.
&Verbar;Keratosa: An order of sponges having a skeleton composed of hornlike fibers. It includes the commercial sponges.
Knockings: Large lumps picked out of the sieve, in dressing ore.
Knightliness: The character or bearing suitable for a knight; chivalry.
Knee-deep: Rising to the knees; knee-high; as, water or snow knee-deep.
Knight service: The military service by rendering which a knight held his lands.
Knight banneret: A knight who carried a banner, who possessed fiefs to a greater amount than the knight bachelor, and who was obliged to serve in war with a greater number of attendants. The dignity was sometimes conferred by the sovereign in person on the field of battle.
Kinesodic: Conveying motion; as, kinesodic substance; -- applied esp. to the spinal cord, because it is capable of conveying doth voluntary and reflex motor impulses, without itself being affected by motor impulses applied to it directly.
kanchil: A small chevrotain of the genus Tragulus, esp. Tragulus pygmæus, or Tragulus kanchil, inhabiting Java, Sumatra, and adjacent islands; a deerlet.  It is noted for its agility and cunning.
Knock: A blow; a stroke with something hard or heavy; a jar.
Kodiak bear: A large brown bear (Ursus middendorffi syn. Ursus arctos middendorffi) of coastal Alaska and British Columbia related to the grizzly bear; called also Kodiak bear.
Killigrew: The Cornish chough. See under Chough.
Kinkajou: A nocturnal carnivorous mammal (Cercoleptes caudivolvulus) of South America, about as large as a full-grown cat. It has a prehensile tail and lives in trees. It is the only representative of a distinct family (Cercoleptidæ) allied to the raccoons. Called also potto, and honey bear.
Kincob: India silk brocaded with flowers in silver or gold.
Kaka: A New Zealand parrot of the genus Nestor, especially the brown parrot (Nestor meridionalis).
Kilerg: A unit of work equal to one thousand ergs.
kopeck: A small Russian coin, continued as a unit of currency within the Soviet Union.  One hundred kopecks make a ruble.  The ruble was worth about sixty cents (U. S.) in 1910; in 1991 a two-kopeck coin could be used for a local telephone call at a pay telephone.  After the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1993, the exchange value of the ruble declined rapidly and by the end of 1994 the ruble was worth three hundredths of a cent, and by 1997 two hundredths of a cent. By 1993, the kopek had become of such small value that it was obsolete and no longer minted.
kopje: A hillock; a small kop, especially a small hill rising up from the African veld.
kimono: A kind of loose robe or gown tied with a sash, worn as a traditional outer garment by Japanese women and men.  Women may wear it with a broad sash called an obi, having a large bow in the back.  At present (1998), most Japanese wear it only at home or on ceremonial occasions, western-style clothing being more common in the workplace.
Knight-errant: A wandering knight; a knight who traveled in search of adventures, for the purpose of exhibiting military skill, prowess, and generosity.
Knapsack: A case of canvas, leather, nylon, or other sturdy fabric, fitted with straps, for carrying on the back the food, clothing, or other supplies for a soldier or a traveler; as, to hike up the mountain with lunch in a knapsack.
Keraunograph: A figure or picture impressed by lightning upon the human body or elsewhere.
kidnapping: the unlawful act of capturing and carrying away a person against their will and holding them in false imprisonment.
knowhow: the knowledge and skill required to do something; practical knowledge for a specific task.
konini: An erect deciduous shrub or tree (Fuchsia excorticata), native to New Zealand, growing up to 10 feet, with maroon-flushed flowers.
Kings Bench: Formerly, the highest court of common law in England; -- so called because the king used to sit there in person. It consisted of a chief justice and four puisne, or junior, justices. During the reign of a queen it was called the Queen's Bench. Its jurisdiction was transferred by the judicature acts of 1873 and 1875 to the high court of justice created by that legislation.
Kickable: Capable or deserving of being kicked.
Kibe: A chap or crack in the flesh occasioned by cold; an ulcerated chilblain.
Knight-errantry: The character or actions of wandering knights; the practice of wandering in quest of adventures; chivalry; a quixotic or romantic adventure or scheme.
Ketone: One of a large class of organic substances resembling the aldehydes, obtained by the distillation of certain salts of organic acids and consisting of carbonyl (CO) united with two hydrocarbon radicals. In general the ketones are colorless volatile liquids having a pungent ethereal odor.
Karat: the unit of measurement for the proportion of gold in an alloy; 18-karat gold is 75 2.122e-314old; 24-karat gold is pure gold.
Kakapo: A singular nocturnal parrot (Strigops habroptilus), native of New Zealand. It lives in holes during the day, but is active at night. It resembles an owl in its colors and general appearance. It has large wings, but can fly only a short distance. Called also owl parrot, night parrot, and night kaka.
Knickknack: A trifle or toy; a bawble; a gewgaw; a tchotchke.
Kaleidoscope: An instrument invented by Sir David Brewster, which contains loose fragments of colored glass, etc., and reflecting surfaces so arranged that changes of position exhibit its contents in an endless variety of beautiful colors and symmetrical forms. It has been much employed in arts of design.
Khalka: the dialect of Mongolian that is the official language of the Mongolian People's Republic.
Katastate: A substance formed by a catabolic process; -- opposed to anastate. See catabolic.
knockoff: A cheap imitation of something popular, produced illegally without a license from the trademark owner, and of inferior materials.
Ketine: One of a series of organic bases obtained by the reduction of certain isonitroso compounds of the ketones. In general they are unstable oily substances having a pungent aromatic odor.
Knee jerk: emotional and predictable; -- of certain people and their reactions to events.
Kwajalein: A battle of World War II (January 1944); American forces landed and captured a Japanese airbase.
Kayak: A light canoe, made of skins stretched over a frame, and usually capable of carrying but one person, who sits amidships and uses a double-bladed paddle. It is peculiar to the Eskimos and other Arctic tribes.
Kin\u00e6sthetic: Of, pertaining to, or involving, kinaesthesia.
Knotgrass: a common weed with jointed stems (Polygonum aviculare); knotweed.
kepi: A military cap having a close-fitting band, a round flat top sloping toward the front, and a visor.  As originally worn by the French in Algeria about 1830 it was tall and stiff with a straight visor. It is now lower, has a curved visor, and is frequently soft.
Katydid: A large, green, arboreal, orthopterous insect (Cyrtophyllus concavus) of the family Locustidæ, common in the United States. The males have stridulating organs at the bases of the front wings. During the summer and autumn, in the evening, the males make a peculiar, loud, shrill sound, resembling the combination Katy-did, whence the name.
Karn: A pile of rocks; sometimes, the solid rock. See Cairn.
Knife switch: A switch consisting of one or more knifelike pieces hinged at one end and making contact near the other with flat gripping springs.
Kosteletzya: A small genus of herbs of the Southeastern U. S. and tropical America and Africa.
Knab: To seize with the teeth; to gnaw.
Knarl: A knot in wood. See Gnarl.
kowhai: A shrub or small tree (Sophora tetraptera) of New Zealand and Chile having pendulous racemes of tubular golden-yellow flowers; it yields a hard strong wood.
Knag: A knot in wood; a protuberance.
knowledgeable: thoroughly acquainted with and skilled in something through study or experience; as, knowledgeable in classical languages.  Opposite of unversed, unacquainted, and unfamiliar.
Kilkenny cats: Two cats fabled, in an Irish story, to have fought till nothing was left but their tails. It is probably a parable of a local contest between Kilkenny and Irishtown, which impoverished both towns.
Kent bugle: A curved bugle, having six finger keys or stops, by means of which the performer can play upon every key in the musical scale; -- called also keyed bugle, and key bugle.
Knee jerk liberal: a person of strong liberal convictions who reacts predictably and emotionally to certain events.
Kerana: A kind of long trumpet, used among the Persians.
Kleenex: A piece of soft absorbent tissue paper (usually two or more thin layers) used as a disposable handkerchief; -- still a current trademark, but often used generically.
Kenyan: Of or pertaining to Kenya; as, Kenyan mountains; Kenyan coffee.
knock-kneed: Having the legs bent inward so that the knees touch in walking.
Knightage: The body of knights, taken collectively.
Kon: To know. See Can, and Con.
Knop: A knob; a bud; a bunch; a button.
Krems: A variety of white lead. See Krems lead, under Lead, n.
knish: A fried, or sometimes baked, turnover made from a round or square sheet of dough containing a filling, usually of meat or potatoes.
Kickshaws: Something fantastical; any trifling, trumpery thing; a toy.
Keyhole: A hole or apertupe in a door or lock, for receiving a key.
Kirtle: A garment varying in form and use at different times, and worn both by men and women.
Kinsfolk: Relatives; kindred; kin; kinfolk; persons of the same family or closely related families.
kumquat: any of several trees or shrubs of the genus Fortunella (formerly Citrus) of the rue family (Rutaceae) (especially Citrus Japonica) growing in China and Japan bearing small orange-colored edible fruits with thick sweet-flavored skin and sour pulp; also, any of the small acid, orange-colored citrus fruits of such plants, used mostly for preserves.
Kamala: The red dusty hairs of the capsules of an East Indian tree (Mallotus Philippinensis) used for dyeing silk. It is violently emetic, and is used in the treatment of tapeworm.
Kob: Any one of several species of African antelopes of the genus Kobus, esp. the species Kobus sing-sing.
&Verbar;Koel: Any one of several species of cuckoos of the genus Eudynamys, found in India, the East Indies, and Australia.  They deposit their eggs in the nests of other birds.
Kharkov: A city in Ukraine; -- its former capital.
Keta: A small salmon (Oncorhynchus keta) of inferior value, which in the autumn runs up all the larger rivers between San Francisco and Kamchatka.
Kaleidophon: An instrument invented by Professor Wheatstone, consisting of a reflecting knob at the end of a vibrating rod or thin plate, for making visible, in the motion of a point of light reflected from the knob, the paths or curves corresponding with the musical notes produced by the vibrations.
Knight-er-ratic: Pertaining to a knight-errant or to knight-errantry.
Knobby: Full of, or covered with, knobs or hard protuberances.
kangaroo rat: A jumping rodent of the genus Dipodomys of the family Heteromyidae, which lives in arid regions of Mexico and the western U. S.
Konseal: A form of capsule for inclosing a dose of medicine that is offensive, caustic, or the like.
&Verbar;Kriegsspiel: A game of war, played for practice, on maps.
Klamaths: A collective name for the Indians of several tribes formerly living along the Klamath river, in California and Oregon, but now restricted to a reservation at Klamath Lake; -- called also Clamets and Hamati.
Knitter: One who, or that which, knits, joins, or unites; a knitting machine.
Keynesian: Of or pertaining to John Maynard Keynes; conforming to the theories of Keynesianism; -- especially, the term is used to refer to the macroeconomic theories and politico-economic policies proposed by Keynes and his followers, especially in regards to their advocacy of governmental action to maintain low unemployment through government spending.  Keynes's book “The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money” (Macmillan, 1936) had a strong influence on views of the government's role in the economy through the 1970's.
Kefir: An effervescent liquor like kumiss, made from fermented milk, used as a food and as a medicine in the northern Caucasus.
Kenogenesis: Modified evolution, in which nonprimitive characters make their appearance in consequence of a secondary adaptation of the embryo to the peculiar conditions of its environment; -- distinguished from palingenesis.
Kurilian: Of or pertaining to the Kurile Islands, a chain of islands in the Pacific ocean, extending from the southern extremity of Kamchatka to Yesso.
Konze: A large African antelope (Alcelaphus Lichtensteini), allied to the hartbeest, but having shorter and flatter horns, and lacking a black patch on the face.
Kinology: That branch of physics which treats of the laws of motion, or of moving bodies.
Knoppern: A kind of gall produced by a gallfly on the cup of an acorn, -- used in tanning and dyeing.
Kindergartner: One who teaches in a kindergarten.
Keynote: The tonic or first tone of the scale in which a piece or passage is written; the fundamental tone of the chord, to which all the modulations of the piece are referred; -- called also key tone.
Kingston metal: An alloy of tin, copper, and mercury, sometimes used for the bearings and packings of machinery.
Kohl-rabi: A variety of cabbage, in which the edible part is a large, turnip-shaped swelling of the stem, above the surface of the ground.
kwela: A kind of danceable music popular among black South Africans; it includes a whistle among its instruments.
Kerosene: An oil used for illuminating purposes, formerly obtained from the distillation of mineral wax, bituminous shale, etc., and hence called also coal oil. It is now produced in immense quantities, chiefly by the distillation and purification of petroleum. It consists chiefly of several hydrocarbons of the methane series, having from 10 to 16 carbon atoms in each molecule, and having a higher boiling point (175 - 325° C) than gasoline or the petroleum ethers, and a lower boling point than the oils.
Killer: One who deprives of life; one who, or that which, kills.
Kingston valve: A conical valve, opening outward, to close the mouth of a pipe which passes through the side of a vessel below the water line.
Kiddle: A kind of basketwork weir in a river, for catching fish.
Kirumbo: A bird of Madagascar (Leptosomus discolor), the only living type of a family allied to the rollers. It has a pair of loral plumes. The male is glossy green above, with metallic reflections; the female is spotted with brown and black.
knowledge engineering: The application of computerized data and text manipulation to manage and interpret large bodies of knowledge, or find useful information in large bodies of data.  The study of methods for knowledge engineering is generally considered as a branch of artificial intelligence.
Kirmess: In Europe, particularly in Belgium and Holland, and outdoor festival and fair; in the United States, generally an indoor entertainment and fair combined.
kilter: Regular order or proper condition.  Same as kelter, but kilter is the more common spelling in the U. S.  Used chiefly in the phrase out of kilter, meaning out of order or irregular in some manner.
Kava: A species of Macropiper (Macropiper methysticum), the long pepper, from the root of which an intoxicating beverage is made by the Polynesians, by a process of mastication; also, the beverage itself.
Kenspeckle: Having so marked an appearance as easily to be recognized.
&Verbar;Keddah: An inclosure constructed to entrap wild elephants; an elephant trap.
Kipskin: Leather prepared from the skin of young or small cattle, intermediate in grade between calfskin and cowhide.
Kickapoos: A tribe of Indians which formerly occupied the region of Northern Illinois, allied in language to the Sacs and Foxes.
Knives: n. pl. of Knife. See Knife.
Karma: One's acts considered as fixing one's lot in the future existence.
Kindle: To take fire; to begin to burn with flame; to start as a flame.
keratin: A sulfur-containing fibrous protein constituting the main structural protein of hard epidermal tissues, such as horn, hair, feathers, nails, claws, hoofs, and the like. It is an insoluble substance, and, unlike elastin, is not dissolved even by gastric or pancreatic juice. By decomposition with sulphuric acid it yields leucine and tyrosine plus various other acid-stable amino acids.  The amino acid composition varies, but it usually has a high percentage of cystine, which stabilizes and insolubilizes the protein by forming intrachain linkages.  A softer form of keratin is present in the epidermis and whalebone.  Called also epidermose.
Kibble: A large iron bucket used in Cornwall and Wales for raising ore out of mines.
Kettledrum: A drum made of thin copper in the form of a hemispherical kettle, with parchment stretched over the mouth of it.
Kafka: Franz Kafka, a writer, b. 1883, d. 1924.
Kreutzer: A small copper coin formerly used in South Germany; also, a small Austrian copper coin.
Kernelly: Full of kernels; resembling kernels; of the nature of kernels.
Keratogenous: Producing horn; as, the keratogenous membrane within the horny hoof of the horse.
Kerasin: A nitrogenous substance free from phosphorus, supposed to be present in the brain; a body closely related to cerebrin.
Kymographic: Of or pertaining to a kymograph; as, a kymographic tracing.
Kurd: A member of a people who inhabit a mountainous region of Western Asia, sometimes referred to as Kurdistan, spread over an area including adjoining parts of Turkey, Iran, Iraq, Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Syria.  The people of this region speak Kurdish and are mostly Moslem.
Kingship: The state, office, or dignity of a king; royalty.
knuckle under: To yield; to submit; -- usually used with to.
Keystone: The central or topmost stone of an arch. This in some styles is made different in size from the other voussoirs, or projects, or is decorated with carving. See Illust. of Arch.
Korean: Of or pertaining to Korea; as, Korean handicrafts; the Korean war.
kissing cousin: A cousin sufficiently well acquainted to be greeted with a kiss; a type of kissing kin.
Katsuwonus: A genus of oceanic bonitos; in some classifications it is placed in its own family Katsuwonidae.
Keelhaul: To haul under the keel of a ship, by ropes attached to the yardarms on each side. It was formerly practiced as a punishment in the Dutch and English navies.
Kaleidoscopic: Of, pertaining to, or formed by, a kaleidoscope; variegated.
Kythe: To come into view; to appear.
Knebelite: A mineral of a gray, red, brown, or green color, and glistening luster. It is a silicate of iron and manganese.
kand: Fluor spar; -- so called by Cornish miners.
Kussier: A Turkish instrument of music, with a hollow body covered with skin, over which five strings are stretched.
&Verbar;Krishna: The most popular of the Hindu divinities, usually held to be the eighth incarnation of the god Vishnu.
Kidney-form: Having the form or shape of a kidney; reniform; as, a kidney-shaped leaf; a kidney-shaped swimming pool.
ka: A spiritual aspect of the individual, living within the body during life, and surviving the body after death.  It was believed to be one of two spirits inhabiting the body, the other being the ba, which deserts teh body at death.
&Verbar;Keitloa: A black, two-horned, African rhinoceros (Atelodus keitloa). It has the posterior horn about as long as the anterior one, or even longer.
Kinit: A unit of force equal to the force which, acting for one second, will give a pound a velocity of one foot per second; -- proposed by J. D. Everett, an English physicist.
kitchenware: Implements for use in a kitchen, or for cooking, such as pots, pans, ladles, measuring cups, etc.
Karroo: One of the dry table-lands of South Africa, which often rise terracelike to considerable elevations.
Kissingcrust: The portion of the upper crust of a loaf which has touched another loaf in baking.
Kinnikinic: Prepared leaves or bark of certain plants; -- used by the Indians of the Northwest for smoking, either mixed with tobacco or as a substitute for it. Also, a plant so used, as the osier cornel (Cornus stolonijra), and the bearberry (Arctostaphylus Uva-ursi).
Klipdas: A small mammal (Hyrax Capensis), found in South Africa. It is of about the size of a rabbit, and closely resembles the daman. Called also rock rabbit.
knock-down-and-drag-out: marked by extreme violence; -- of fights; also used metaphorically of fierce contests; as, a knock-down-and-drag-out fight; a knockdown-dragout competition for the browser market.
&Verbar;Kuda: The East Indian tapir. See Tapir.
Kynurenic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from the urine of dogs. By decomposition the acid yields a nitrogenous base (called kynurin) and carbonic acid.
kiss-me-over-the-garden-gate: An annual (Polygonum orientale) with broadly ovate leaves and slender drooping spikes of crimson flowers; it is native to Southeastern Asia and Australia, and naturalized in North America.
Keld: Having a kell or covering; webbed.
Karatas: A West Indian plant of the Pineapple family (Nidularium Karatas).
knocked-out: damaged; -- not used of persons; as, the gym has some of the most knocked-out equipment since Vic Tanny.  Opposite of undamaged.
Kell: The caul; that which covers or envelops as a caul; a net; a fold; a film.
Knead: To work and press into a mass, usually with the hands; esp., to work, as by repeated pressure with the knuckles, into a well mixed mass, as the materials of bread, cake, etc.; as, to knead dough.
Kauri resin: A resinous product of the kauri, found in the form of yellow or brown lumps in the ground where the trees have grown. It is used for making varnish, and as a substitute for amber.
Kelt: Same as Celt, one of Celtic race.
Kinesiatrics: A mode of treating disease by appropriate muscular movements; -- also termed kinesitherapy, kinesipathy, lingism, and the movement cure.
Kelp: The calcined ashes of seaweed, -- formerly much used in the manufacture of glass, now used in the manufacture of iodine.
Kamichi: A curious South American bird (Anhima  or Palamedea cornuta), often domesticated by the natives and kept with poultry, which it defends against birds of prey. It has a long, slender, hornlike ornament on its head, and two sharp spurs on each wing. Although its beak, feet, and legs resemble those of gallinaceous birds, it is related in anatomical characters to the ducks and geese (Anseres). Called also horned screamer. The name is sometimes applied also to the chaja. See Chaja, and Screamer.
Kennedia: A genus of Australian woody vines having showy red or purplish flowers.
Kick: A blow with the foot or feet; a striking or thrust with the foot.
Knifeboard: A board on which knives are cleaned or polished.
Knob: To grow into knobs or bunches; to become knobbed.
Kantian: A follower of Kant; a Kantist.
kissing disease: Infectious mononucleosis; -- so called because often spread by kissing.
klavier: a stringed instrument that has a keyboard, especially a piano, harpsichord, or clavichord; also, the keyboard of such an instrument.  Same as clavier.
kidskin: A soft smooth leather from the hide of a young goat; kid{3}.
Kitish: Like or relating to a kite.
Krooman: One of a negro tribe of Liberia and the adjacent coast, whose members are much employed on shipboard.
Know: To have knowledge; to have a clear and certain perception; to possess wisdom, instruction, or information; -- often with of.
Knot: To form knots or joints, as in a cord, a plant, etc.; to become entangled.
Knockstone: A block upon which ore is broken up.
Kindness: The state or quality of being kind, in any of its various senses; manifestation of kind feeling or disposition beneficence.
Koumiss: An intoxicating fermented or distilled liquor originally made by the Tartars of central Asia from mare's or camel's milk. It can be obtained from any kind of milk, and is now largely made in Europe.
Kerseys: Varieties of kersey; also, trousers made of kersey.
Kurdish: The language of the Kurds; it is related to Farsi, the modern Iranian language.
kitambilla: A small shrubby spiny tree (Dovyalis hebecarpa) cultivated for its maroon-purple fruit with sweet purple pulp tasking like gooseberries; it is native to Sri Lanka and India.
Kenogenetic: Of or pertaining to kenogenesis; as, kenogenetic processes.
Kampylite: A variety of mimetite or arseniate of lead in hexagonal prisms of a fine orange yellow.
Kilogrammeter: A measure of energy or work done, being the amount expended in raising one kilogram through the height of one meter, in the latitude of Paris.
Kilovolt: A unit of electromotive force equal to one thousand volts.
Kogia: The genus comprising the pygmy sperm whales.
Koran: The Scriptures of the Muslims, containing the professed revelations to Mohammed; -- called also Alcoran.
&Verbar;Karyomiton: The reticular network of fine fibers, of which the nucleus of a cell is in part composed; -- in opposition to kytomiton, or the network in the body of the cell.
Krupp process: A process practiced by Friedrich Krupp, Essen, Germany, for washing pig iron, differing from the Bell process in using manganese as well as iron oxide, and performed in a Pernot furnace.  Called also the Bell-Krupp process.
Knaveship: A small due, in meal, established by usage, which is paid to the under miller.
Kodak: To photograph with a kodak; hence, to describe or characterize briefly and vividly.
Karyokinetic: Of or pertaining to karyokinesis; as, karyokinetic changes of cell division.
Katabolism: Destructive or downward metabolism; regressive metamorphism; same as catabolism (now the more common spelling); -- opposed to anabolism. See Disassimilation.
Ketonic: Pertaining to, or derived from, a ketone; as, a ketonic acid.
Kittiwake: A northern gull (Rissa tridactyla), inhabiting the coasts of Europe and America.  It is white, with black tips to the wings, and has only three toes.
Know-all: One who knows everything; hence, one who makes pretension to great knowledge; a wiseacre; a know-it-all; -- usually ironical.
kissing kin: Any relative more distant than the immediate family, sufficiently well acquainted to be greeted with a kiss, such as a kissing cousin.
Keener: A professional mourner who wails at a funeral.
Kidnap: To take (any one) by force or fear, and against one's will, with intent to carry to another place.
kurakkan: An East Indian cereal grass (Eleusine coracana) whose seed yield a somewhat bitter flour, a staple in the Orient.
Keratome: An instrument for dividing the cornea in operations for cataract.
Kitchenry: The body of servants employed in the kitchen; the staff of a kitchen.
